Thank you so much for being part of today‚Äôs session ü§óüå∏

Here are the resources we went through, in case you‚Äôd like to revisit them at home:

Thank you so much for being part of today‚Äôs session ü§óüå∏

rows.title::eng: Send this message after your in-person session
rows.text::eng:
Thank you so much for being part of today‚Äôs session ü§óüå∏
It was wonderful to learn and share together.

Here are the resources we went through, in case you‚Äôd like to revisit them at home:

Hey there! üëã Just checking in with a friendly reminder to try this week‚Äôs home activity:

Spend a few minutes of One-on-One Time with your child ‚Äìno distractions, just the two of you!

Here‚Äôs something to keep in mind:
Even short moments of focused attention help your child feel truly seen and loved. It strengthens your bond and reminds them that what they do is important. üíñ

You‚Äôre doing great! Keep it up!
Hello! I look forward to hearing how the rest of your week goes when we next meet on [ENTER DATE HERE]. Chat then!
rows.guidance::eng: Replace [ENTER DATE HERE] with the date of the chat session

rows.text::eng: Hello and thanks for being part of the @global.prog_name chat! I am thrilled to be able to chat together about how we can best support our children to grow up healthy and happy. Today, we are going to chat about spending One-on-One time with your children.

Let‚Äôs introduce ourselves! Please share your name and your goal for the programme. As an example, my name is [INSERT NAME] and I want to learn more about how to help my child go to bed by 8 every night. Feel free to add your own to the chat using text or audio message.
rows.guidance::eng: Allow some time for parents to share.  Remember to praise each response. For example, you can say ‚ÄúThanks for the response, [Insert Name]!‚Äù or ‚ÄúGreat goal, [Insert Name]!‚Äù

rows.text::eng:
Thanks so much for sharing! To make this a safe space to communicate openly let‚Äôs make some ground rules for this chat group. Our first rule is that what is said in the group stays in the group. You need to know that this group is private.
Here are some other examples to start us off:
üì± Let me know if you need to miss a chat session.
ü©µ Accept each other. Everyone is different and has different experiences.
üí¨ Share only what you feel comfortable sharing.
‚ùì Feel free to ask questions!
üîè Respect the privacy of personal pictures and videos that are sent to the chat group. 

Does anyone have any additional rules that they want to suggest?
rows.guidance::eng: Allow a couple minutes for parents to share. Praise suggestions and contributions. Make sure that everyone agrees on the ground rules.

rows.title::eng: Message 4: Checking in on home activity
rows.text::eng:
Have you had a chance to try spending One-on-One Time with your child?
If you did, give me a thumbs up! üëçüèΩ
rows.guidance::eng: Acknowledge the thumbs up with thumbs up, emojis, or quick words of praise.

rows.title::eng: Message 5: Voting on a challenge to discuss
rows.text::eng:
If you gave a thumbs up ‚Äî amazing! üéâIf you face some challenges during one-on-one time, that's completely normal. You‚Äôre not alone! Here are some common challenges caregivers have experienced. Vote for the one you‚Äôd like us to talk about together:

1Ô∏è‚É£ I didn‚Äôt have enough time
2Ô∏è‚É£ My child did not want to spend time with me
3Ô∏è‚É£ All my child wanted to do was watch TV or play with a gadget
4Ô∏è‚É£ My child wanted to do things I felt uncomfortable about
Can we work together to think of a positive solution to [name challenge]?
rows.guidance::eng: Choose the challenge with the highest vote. Encourage parents to work together to identify positive solutions. Here are some possible solutions to the challenges.

rows.text::eng: Thanks for discussing that challenge with me! Does anyone have any other challenges you‚Äôd like us to troubleshoot together? Feel free to share ‚Äî we‚Äôre here to support each other!

Before we end today‚Äôs session let‚Äôs take a pause together. This is something you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or overwhelmed. I really appreciate everyone‚Äôs contribution today. I‚Äôll be in touch throughout the week with reminders about what‚Äôs coming next. Until then, have a peaceful and happy day!

Let‚Äôs see a story of parents talking about a difficult emotion with their teen
üí°Here are 5 things about how to talk about emotions with your children & your home activity for the week.
üëã Hey there! It‚Äôs time for another parenting story. Today‚Äôs story is about helping your children to manage their feelings.
Let‚Äôs look at a story that shows a child talking about emotions while they are spending one-on-one time with their parent
üí°Here are 5 things about how to talk about emotions with your children & your home activity for the week.
üëã Hey there! It‚Äôs time for another parenting story. Today‚Äôs story is about helping your children to manage their feelings.
Let‚Äôs see a story of parents talking about a difficult emotion with their teen.
üí°Here are 5 things about how to talk about emotions with your children & your home activity for the week.

Hello! Remember this week‚Äôs home practice is to try to talk about emotions with your children during one-on-one time and other times during the week. 

Talking about emotions helps children learn that all feelings are okay‚Äîeven the big or tricky ones. This makes it easier for them to understand themselves and talk to you about what they‚Äôre going through. üòäüí¨

Can you believe that a whole week has gone by? Our next chat session will be later at [INSERT DATE & TIME]. We will continue learning about the benefits of talking about emotions with our children. Chat soon!
rows.guidance::eng: Replace [INSERT DATE & TIME] with the date of the chat session

rows.text::eng: Welcome to Module 2 of @global.prog_name! How is everybody doing? Happy? Stressed? Angry? Annoyed? Peaceful? Whatever emotion you feel‚Ä¶it‚Äôs okay! Please feel free to share how you are feeling today.
rows.guidance::eng: Allow time for parents to share how they are feeling. You should also share how you are feeling. For example, ‚ÄúI am happy to be part of the chat today.‚Äù

rows.title::eng: Message 2: Checking in on home activity
rows.text::eng:
Last time, we focused on helping children talk about their feelings.
If you found a moment to talk about emotions, whether during one-on-one time or another time in the week, give me a thumbs up! üëçüèΩ
rows.guidance::eng: Acknowledge the thumbs up with thumbs up, emojis, or quick words of praise.

rows.title::eng: Message 3: Voting on a challenge to discuss
rows.text::eng:
Great job if you were able to give it a try! üôåüèæ If starting conversations about emotions felt a bit tough, that‚Äôs totally understandable. Many parents and caregivers go through the same thing. Take a look at the challenges below and choose the one you‚Äôd like us to explore together:

1Ô∏è‚É£ My child did not want to share their feelings 
2Ô∏è‚É£ I felt uncomfortable talking about my feelings
3Ô∏è‚É£ I was afraid my child might think I am weak for sharing my own emotions
4Ô∏è‚É£ I was too stressed or angry to share my emotions, I prefer to be alone when I feel like that.
Can we work together to think of a positive solution to [name challenge]?
rows.guidance::eng: Replace [name challenge] with the challenge with the highest vote. Encourage parents to work together to identify positive solutions. Here are some possible solutions to the challenges.

rows.text::eng: I appreciate you opening up about that! Are there any other challenging moments you‚Äôve run into? You‚Äôre welcome to bring them up, this is a space where we can help each other out.

Before we end today‚Äôs chat session, let's take a pause together. Remember that this is something you can do whenever you are feeling stressed, or your children are annoying you. 

Thank you. The work you have done today is hard work ‚Äì but it‚Äôs also very valuable work. It will help you to manage your own stress and give your children the tools they need to manage theirs. Have a peaceful and happy day!
üëã Hey there! Welcome to Module 3 of @global.prog_name. Well done for making the time today. We will be chatting about how to help our children follow instructions.
Let‚Äôs look at a story that shows a parent giving specific and positive instructions to their teen:
Let‚Äôs see a story of parents giving praise to their child for following instructions:
Now let‚Äôs move on to the parenting tip. Here are 3 steps to help you to get your children to follow your instructions more often:
üëã Hey there! Welcome to Module 3 of @global.prog_name. Well done for making the time today. We will be chatting about how to help our children follow instructions.
Let‚Äôs see a story of parents giving praise to their child for following instructions:

üëã Hey there! Welcome to Module 3 of @global.prog_name. Well done for making the time today. We will be chatting about how to help our children follow instructions.
Let‚Äôs look at a story that shows a parent giving specific and positive instructions to their teen:
Now let‚Äôs move on to the parenting tip. Here are 3 steps to help you to get your children to follow your instructions more often:

Hello! Keep spending 5 minutes of one-on-one time with your child every day. Remember to practice keeping your instructions positive, realistic, and specific and to praise your children for following instructions. 

Some of things you can praise your child for are playing quietly, talking respectfully to others, and helping with chores around the house. 

Thank you for your commitment and dedication to your children!

Hello! Can you believe that another week has gone by? Our next chat session will be later at [INSERT DATE & TIME]. We will continue chatting about how to get your children to follow instructions. Chat soon!

rows.title::eng: Message 2: Checking in on home activity
rows.text::eng: How did your home practice go this week? As a reminder, for home practice you were going to practice giving specific, realistic, and positive instructions and praise your children when they followed an instruction. Give me a üëçüèΩif you were able to give it a try!
rows.guidance::eng: Acknowledge the thumbs up with thumbs up, emojis, or quick words of praise.

rows.title::eng: Message 3: Voting on a challenge to discuss
rows.text::eng:
Awesome if you had a chance to try it out! üôåüèæ If giving clear instructions or remembering to praise your child feels a bit challenging, you‚Äôre not alone. Many caregivers find this takes practice. Check out the challenges below and pick the one you‚Äôd like us to talk through together:

1Ô∏è‚É£ My child did not follow my instructions, even when I used the tips. 
2Ô∏è‚É£ I forgot to praise my child. 
3Ô∏è‚É£ I shouted at my child when they behaved negatively instead of giving them a positive instruction for what they should do.
4Ô∏è‚É£ It is hard to remember to use positive words when giving instructions.
Can we work together to think of a positive solution to [name challenge]?
rows.guidance::eng: Choose the challenge with the highest vote. Encourage parents to work together to identify positive solutions. Here are some possible challenges and solutions.

rows.text::eng: Thanks for sharing that! Have you come across any other difficult situations lately? Feel free to share, this is a space where we can support one another.

Before we end today‚Äôs module, let's take a pause together. Remember that this is something you can do whenever you are feeling stressed, or your children are annoying you.

Thank you for working as hard as you do as parents. The commitment you are showing to improving the lives of your children just by being here is worth the final note of praise in our module today: Truly well done.

üëã Welcome to Module 4 of @global.prog_name! Can you believe it that we are already more than halfway through the programme? Well done for making it this far! Today we will be chatting about how to keep our children safe by creating household rules and daily routines.

üëã Welcome to Module 4 of @global.prog_name! Can you believe it that we are already more than halfway through the programme? Well done for making it this far! Today we will be chatting about how to keep our children safe by creating household rules and daily routines.
Let‚Äôs look at a story about parents making a rule about tablet use with their teen:
Now let‚Äôs move on to today‚Äôs parent tip. Here are 4 steps you can take to help your children follow household rules and routines:

Hello! You should try to involve your children and other members of your household when making new rules and routines. These can be around bedtime, schoolwork or chores. 

It is perfectly normal for children to test out rules before making them a normal part of the routine. Soon these rules and routines will just feel like a normal part of your household and day. Daily routines can help create a sense of security in the household. 

Thank you!
Hello! It is the time of the week again! Our next session will be later at [INSERT DATE & TIME]. We will be learning about how to make rules and routines with our children. Chat soon!

Great if you were able to give it a go! üôåüèæ If coming up with a household rule or setting a routine felt a little tough, you‚Äôre definitely not the only one. Lots of caregivers are figuring it out too. Take a look at the challenges below and choose the one you‚Äôd like us to chat about together:

1Ô∏è‚É£ We were not able to stick to the rule
2Ô∏è‚É£ My child and I could not agree on a rule
3Ô∏è‚É£ I felt uncomfortable, because I feel parents should be the one establishing the rule not my child
4Ô∏è‚É£ Another caregiver at home didn‚Äôt agree with the rule
Can we work together to think of a positive solution to [name challenge]?
rows.guidance::eng: Choose the challenge with the highest vote. Encourage parents to work together to identify positive solutions. Here are some possible challenges and solutions.

rows.text::eng: Thanks for opening up! Have there been any other moments that felt challenging recently? Don‚Äôt hesitate to share, this is a space where we‚Äôre all here to help each other.

Before we end today‚Äôs module let‚Äôs take a pause together. Remember that this is something you can do whenever you are feeling stressed, or your children are annoying you.

Thank you so much for a wonderful session. I hope the rules and routines you introduce into your homes help make your household more manageable. Have a peaceful and happy day!

üëã Welcome to Module 5 of @global.prog_name! This week, we‚Äôll talk about positive discipline ‚Äì calm, practical and positive ways to respond when our children misbehave. It‚Äôs not about letting children do whatever they want. Positive discipline helps us guide our children while building a stronger relationship.
Let‚Äôs look at a story that shows how you can redirect your children from negative to positive behaviours before they get worse.
Let‚Äôs look at how parents can use consequences with their children and teens:
Now let‚Äôs chat about today‚Äôs parent tip - how to respond with positive discipline when children misbehave. Here are 3 steps you can follow:

üëã Welcome to Module 5 of @global.prog_name! This week, we‚Äôll talk about positive discipline ‚Äì calm, practical and positive ways to respond when our children misbehave. It‚Äôs not about letting children do whatever they want. Positive discipline helps us guide our children while building a stronger relationship.
Let‚Äôs look at a story that shows how you can redirect your children from negative to positive behaviours before they get worse.
Let‚Äôs look at how parents can use consequences with their children:
Now let‚Äôs chat about today‚Äôs parent tip - how to respond with positive discipline when children misbehave. Here are 3 steps you can follow:

üëã Welcome to Module 5 of @global.prog_name! This week, we‚Äôll talk about positive discipline ‚Äì calm, practical and positive ways to respond when our children misbehave. It‚Äôs not about letting children do whatever they want. Positive discipline helps us guide our children while building a stronger relationship.
Let‚Äôs look at how parents can use consequences with their children:
Now let‚Äôs chat about today‚Äôs parent tip - how to respond with positive discipline when children misbehave. Here are 3 steps you can follow:

Hello! Remember that using new ways to discipline your children takes practice! Try to make sure that consequences should be fair and realistic. They are best used when your child forgets a household rule or refuses to follow an instruction.

It is really important to remember to Keep It Positive! Continue to spend quality time with your children, use positive instructions, and praise them when they are behaving well. The more positive attention they receive for good behaviour, the less you will have to discipline them!
As we start thinking ahead beyond the end of the programme, would anyone like to consider taking on the administrator role for our chat group? DM if you are interested! Thank you!
Hello! It is the time of the week again! Our next session will be later at [INSERT DATE & TIME]. We will be learning about how to make rules and routines with our children. Chat soon!

Well done if you tried it out! üôåüèæ If coming up with a behaviour and consequence felt challenging, you‚Äôre not alone. Many caregivers are still practicing this skill too. Have a look at the challenges below and pick the one you‚Äôd like us to explore together:

1Ô∏è‚É£ I am too angry to find anything positive to say to my child after they have misbehaved.
2Ô∏è‚É£ I got very angry with my child and shouted at them.
3Ô∏è‚É£ I forgot to give my child a chance to do what I asked before giving the consequence.
4Ô∏è‚É£ My child got very angry with me after I gave the consequence for their misbehaviour.
Can we work together to think of a positive solution to [name challenge]?
rows.guidance::eng: Replace [name challenge] with the challenge with the highest vote. Encourage parents to work together to identify positive solutions. Here are some possible challenges and solutions.

rows.text::eng: Thanks for opening up! Have there been any other moments that felt challenging recently? Don‚Äôt hesitate to share, this is a space where we‚Äôre all here to help each other.

Before we end today‚Äôs module let‚Äôs take a short pause together. Remember that this is something you can do whenever you are feeling stressed or overwhelmed. You can also do it to appreciate a positive moment, too! 

What a wonderful session! Have a peaceful and happy day!
üëãWelcome to our last week of @global.prog_name! Today we are going to learn about how to solve problems with our children and reflect on what we have learned in the programme.
Let‚Äôs look at a story about how you can work with your children to find a solution to a problem instead of having to use consequences:
Let's look at how a situation when our children get bullied by others online:

Now let‚Äôs move on to the final parenting tip on problem solving with your children. We have been doing this throughout the programme. Now it is time to learn how we can involve our children in the process! Here are the 4 basic steps for problem solving:
üëãWelcome to our last week of @global.prog_name! Today we are going to learn about how to solve problems with our children and reflect on what we have learned in the programme.

üëãWelcome to our last week of @global.prog_name! Today we are going to learn about how to solve problems with our children and reflect on what we have learned in the programme.
Let's look at how a situation when our children get bullied by others online:

Now let‚Äôs move on to the final parenting tip on problem solving with your children. We have been doing this throughout the programme. Now it is time to learn how we can involve our children in the process! Here are the 4 basic steps for problem solving:
Congratulations! I wanted to share an audio message that might help you reflect on all of the things we explored in the @global.programme_name.
rows.guidance::eng: Send this message with the audio recording

rows.text::eng:
Even though the programme is ending soon, our parenting work continues! Remember to continue practising all of the skills that we have learned together. The main ones are:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Spend one-on-one time with your children. Just 5 minutes a day can make a difference

2Ô∏è‚É£ Praise your children when they are behaving well

3Ô∏è‚É£ Keep it positive with positive instructions

4Ô∏è‚É£ Have consistent household rules and daily routines (including time for play!)

5Ô∏è‚É£ Practice positive discipline with redirect and consequences

6Ô∏è‚É£ Involve  your child in solving problems together.

7Ô∏è‚É£ Take 5 deep breaths or a Pause when you are feeling stressed or angry.
Hello! I hope everybody had a good week! Our final session will be later at [INSERT DATE & TIME].

rows.text::eng: Welcome to Module 6 of @global.prog_name! How is everybody doing? Describe what you are feeling today, where you feel it in your body and what thoughts you associate with the feeling.
rows.guidance::eng: Allow time for parents to share. You should also share how you are feeling. For example, ‚ÄúI am excited to be part of the chat today, and I feel that excitement in my heart.‚Äù

rows.text::eng: Since we are having our last chat session, let‚Äôs take a few moments to reflect on our experience during the programme. Let‚Äôs share some of the things that we learned from the programme or ways that we and our children have changed.
rows.guidance::eng: Give parents time to reflect and respond. You can encourage everyone to have a chance to write something in the chat. Remember to thank each parent for their contribution. If no parents respond, you can prompt by asking parents to share something they are proud of, or something that surprised them.

rows.text::eng: Thank you for sharing. Now you can sit back and enjoy a story that we have shared at the end of all of our parenting programmes.

rows.title::eng: Message 4: Discussion about the stone soup
rows.text::eng: What are some of the ingredients that we have in our group to continue supporting us as parents? In what ways can we continue to support each other after the end of the programme?
rows.guidance::eng: Remember to give parents a chance to respond before moving on to the reflection

rows.title::eng: Message 5: Offer for Questions about ongoing support through the group
rows.text::eng: Thank you to [Insert Name of New Group Administrator] who will be taking over as the group administrator. Do any of you have any questions about how you can continue to use the group going forward?
rows.guidance::eng: Allow a few minutes for parents to raise any questions. Remember to thank parents for their questions and let them take the lead in the ongoing planning for the group.

rows.text::eng:
Let‚Äôs close with an activity that is similar to Taking a Pause. Since it is the last module of the programme, we take this opportunity to reconnect with ourselves and our families through a sense of love and support.

Thank you and well done for completing the ParentChat programme! You have shown great love and commitment to your families by being here. It has been a pleasure to be on this journey with you.

rows.title::eng: Send this message along with the certificates
rows.text::eng:
Congratulations on completing the @global.prog_name! üéâ
Here‚Äôs your certificate to celebrate your dedication and commitment as a parent. We‚Äôre so proud of the love, effort, and learning you‚Äôve put into this journey. Keep going, you‚Äôre making a real difference for your family!

rows.title::eng: Send this message to the group after the closing session
rows.text::eng: Thank you and well done for completing the @global.prog_name! You have shown great love and commitment to your families by being here. It has been a pleasure to be on this journey with you. I wish you all well going forward!
